awd_titl_txt: Supporting Teacher Practice to Facilitate and Assess Oral Scientific Argumentation: Embedding a Real-Time Assessment of Speaking and Listening into an Argumentation-Rich Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an early-stage design and development collaborative study submitted to the assessment strand of the Discovery Research PreK-12 (DRK-12) program, in response to Program Solicitation NSF 15-592. The fundamental purpose of this project is to support teacher practice and professional learning around oral scientific argumentation in order to improve the quality of this practice in classrooms. To achieve this purpose, the project will examine the validity of a new technology-based formative assessment tool for classroom argumentation--"Diagnosing the Argumentation Levels of Groups" (DiALoG)--for which psychometric validation work has been conducted in a laboratory setting. The DiALoG assessment tool allows teachers to document classroom talk and display scores across multiple dimensions--both intrapersonal and interpersonal--for formative assessment purposes. The project will work with 6th-8th grade science teachers to monitor and support argumentation through real-time formative assessment data generated by the DiALoG instrument. DiALoG will be used in conjunction with "Amplify Science", a Lawrence Hall of Science-developed curriculum that incorporates the science practice of engaging in argument from evidence, and a suite of newly developed Responsive Mini-Lessons (RMLs), which consist of 20-30 minute instructional strategies designed to assist teachers to provide feedback to students' thinking and follow-up to argumentation episodes that the DiALoG tool identifies in need of further support. The study will allow the refinement and expansion of DiALoG and evaluation of its impact on teacher pedagogical content knowledge and formative assessment practices in widespread classroom use.

The project will address two specific research questions: (1) How can DiALoG be refined to provide a formative assessment tool for oral argumentation that is reliable, practical, and useful in middle school classrooms?; and (2) How does the use of DiALoG affect teacher formative assessment practices around evidence-based argumentation, when implementing science units designed to support oral argumentation? In order to answer these questions, the project will conduct a randomized control trial with 100 teachers: 50 will teach argumentation-focused curriculum with DiALoG, 50 will teach the same curriculum without DiALoG. Both control and treatment teachers will receive all digital and physical materials needed to teach three Amplify Science curriculum units. Treatment teachers will be provided also with the most recent version of DiALoG, including the linked RMLs, as well as support materials for using DiALoG with the Amplify curriculum. A subgroup of focus teachers (5 from the treatment group, and 5 from the control group) will be the subject of additional data collection and analysis. Three focus lessons, in which students are engaging in small-group or whole-class oral argumentation, will be selected from each of the three Amplify Science curricular units. Teacher measures for the randomized control trial will include validated instruments, such as (a) a pre- and post-assessment of teacher pedagogical content knowledge; (b) post-lesson and post-unit surveys in which teachers will self-report on their formative assessment practices; and (c) video recordings of selected lessons in the focus classrooms. In order to observe potential differences in formative assessment practices between treatment and control, protocols will be used to analyze the video recordings of focus classrooms, including (a) Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol; (b) Assessment of Scientific Argumentation inside the Classroom; and (c) Formative Assessment for Teachers and Students. The key outcome of this work will be a research-informed and field-tested prototype to improve the quality of teaching and learning argumentation in middle school science classrooms usable in different learning environments.

por.por_cntn:
Science teachers have been grappling with new standards that have ambitious expectations for teaching and assessing evidence-based argumentation as a discipline-specific practice. Many current science instructors did not learn science in this way. Thus, as new science standards are being adopted by more and more states, science teachers need support in how to teach science through the practice of argumentation.

 

Assessment is a major area where teachers need support in teaching science through evidence-based argumentation. This includes assessment of oral argumentation, which can be particularly challenging since classroom talk is often quite fluid and non-linear. The ephemeral nature of classroom talk often makes it more difficult to consistently and reliably assess than the assessment of student reading and writing.

 

To address these challenges, this project developed a digital assessment system of oral argumentation called Diagnosing the Argumentation Levels of Groups (DiALoG). The DiALoG system includes a Digital Scoring Tool that allows teachers to assess and annotate the quality of critical speaking and listening taking place when students engage in group discussions. In addition to the Digital Scoring Tool, the DiALoG system also includes User Guides for teacher training as well as Responsive Mini Lessons (RMLs), which are curricula designed to bolster areas the Digital Scoring Tool deems in need of improvement.

 

Project research activities involved middle school teachers across the United States using the DiALoG system to support classroom speaking and listening activities embedded within an argumentation-rich curriculum. For teachers reporting regular use of DiALoG, a common outcome was that DiALoG prompted them to look for and notice specific aspects of classroom speaking and listening they didn’t explicitly consider previously. This allowed teachers to reflect on potential changes necessary for their pedagogy and/or curriculum to better support critical aspects of speaking and listening (e.g., student critique and co-construction of multiple viewpoints). This research yielded 8 peer-reviewed publications, 11 peer-reviewed conference presentations, and a doctoral dissertation.

 

The DiALoG digital assessment system of classroom speaking and listening has been made freely available for educators at:

 

https://dialog.lawrencehallofscience.org/apps/dialog-tool/#!/home

 

For ease of use, the Digital Scoring Tool, RMLs, and User Guides are all embedded within the digital interface found at the above link.

 

For each of the 8 items measured by the DiALoG Digital Scoring Tool, teachers read a prompt describing one aspect of classroom argumentation and then enter on a touch screen whether or not that prompt is not descriptive (Level 0), somewhat descriptive (Level 1), or very descriptive (Level 2) of what they just observed in their classrooms. If teachers determine some of the items on the DiALoG Digital Scoring Tool are scoring at Level 0 or Level 1, the digital interface provides access to downloadable curricular activities (i.e., RMLs) designed to be responsive to the specific speaking and listening levels at which students have been assessed. Accompanying User Guides then aid teachers in utilizing the Digital Scoring Tool to select appropriate RMLs.

 

A professional learning website with free resources was created to assist educators interested in utilizing the DiALoG digital assessment system:

 

https://sites.google.com/berkeley.edu/usingdialog/home

 

An informational video was created to recruit future teachers interested in using what we have developed through this project:

 

https://tinyurl.com/DiALoG-NSTA

 

A short-form version of the above informational video can be found here:

 

https://tinyurl.com/DiAloG-NSTA-ShortForm

 

In a collaborative, 21st Century workforce, the ability to reason respectfully and yet critically with others is a vital skill. This project has developed freely-available curricula, teacher training resources, and a digital assessment system to support critical speaking and listening in science classrooms. This is increasingly necessary in a world where collaboration is the norm and the need is greater than ever before to critically interrogate scientific and technical information stemming from a multitude of different sources and agendas. Furthermore, while this study took place in the context of middle school science, the project generated multiple research products demonstrating how DiALoG can be used as a more general framework to assess and support the oral aspects of argumentation in practically every context.
